captions.text:
As the Christ must once have said as nails
were driven through his palms, sometimes I
wonder why I fucking bother.

I devoted a whole nine brain cells to coming
up with a name for the specific genre of fighting

games that Devil May Cry and Bayonetta fall
into, the kind where defeating all the baddies

is secondary to looking damn sexy while you&#39;re
doing it, and came up with Spectacle Fighters.

Which is a good name, it conveys the important
information, the tumbling syllables of Spectacle

transition nicely into the smooth finish of
fighter, it would fit nicely into a song lyric
- spectacle fighters make testicles lighter.

But then the games industry collectively turns
around and says &quot;We&#39;ve decided we&#39;re going

to call this sort of game &quot;character action&quot;
games.&quot;

Put a straw in your mouth, stick a gas bottle
up your arse and turn yourself into a Soda
Stream.
What the fuck is &quot;character action?&quot;
That doesn&#39;t tell you shit.

Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing features a character
and actions, is that a &quot;character action&quot;
game?

I hope you realise, games industry, that you
need me more than I need you.

There are millions of bathroom walls I could
be writing this shit on.

I had a really good idea for what to call
PUBG clones but I&#39;m not gonna tell you it
now.

Sorry, this was supposed to transition into
a Devil May Cry 5 review at some point but
I lost the thread.
Let&#39;s start again.

Devil May Cry 5 is a... (weird sigh) &quot;character
action&quot; game and direct sequel to Devil May
Cry 1 through 4.

In which case may I be the first to welcome
Ninja Theory&#39;s attempted reboot, DMC: Devil
May Cry, to the dustbin of history.

I hope you have a good time in there hanging
out with the Star Wars Expanded Universe and
most of the Halloween films.

DMC5 is so keen to bring back the previous
canon it&#39;s almost being slightly aggressive
about it.

Old Dante&#39;s back, looking like a member of
Metallica after a near-fatal bleaching accident,
as well as Nero from DMC4.

Yes, the whiny teenage replacement protagonist
that nobody liked.

He&#39;s back with a robot arm and he&#39;s going
to keep coming back with more robot parts

until you do like him, that&#39;s right, we&#39;re
doing the full Raiden on this bitch.

And let&#39;s have every other established character
appear as well even if they&#39;ve got fuck all
to do.

Trish and Lady will both appear, they will
get beaten up, flash their naked botties precisely

once each and then spend the rest of the game
sitting in the back of a van like two old

mattresses you haven&#39;t gotten around to taking
to the dump.

The plot of Devil May Cry 5 is something of
a light touch, but then that&#39;s usually the
case.

An evil demon king has taken over a human
city and in order to protect the humans that

are all already dead Dante and the Scooby
gang who now literally have their own Mystery

Machine have to go in, cockily fight a few
bosses, get beaten up by the unstoppable big

boy a few times before having some kind of
convenient revelation along the lines of &quot;I

will do whatever it takes to protect my luscious
hairdo&quot; and turning into a demon or something.

The only real curveball of the plot is the
third playable character, V, who looks like

Adam Driver auditioning for his high school
production of a Christmas Carol.

More importantly, when you start your first
game, and are asked to pick Human or Devil

Hunter difficulty, I&#39;d advise taking Devil
Hunter.

Only two difficulty settings is a tricky moment
for me, a dedicated medium man.

You don&#39;t want to get stuck with something
too hard when you&#39;ve got deadlines.

So I went for Human, I mean, it seemed like
the sort of thing you&#39;d call a medium-y, average-y
setting.

If there were an insultingly easy mode for
ickle babies they&#39;d have called it Toddler
or Frenchman.

So I played Human and proceeded to S-rank
every level against enemies who couldn&#39;t knock
down my health bar so much as shave it.
Which was a tad disappointing.

I mean, not playing DMC for the challenge
is like going to an Indian restaurant and
ordering nothing but naan breads and raita.

The challenge and stylish combat are the selling
points, and of course those two go together

- the combat wouldn&#39;t feel as stylish if there
wasn&#39;t the possibility of buggering it right
up an unlubricated chimney.

You&#39;ll be disappointed if you play DMC5 for
the plot.

The story really falls apart by the end after
all the reveals are revealed and the last

few chapters descend into something halfway
between Dragonball Z and Days of our Lives.

You&#39;ll also be disappointed if you&#39;re some
kind of interior designer bereft of inspiration

and are playing it for the scenery, because
large chunks of it are just navigating one

washed-out ruined corridor after enough that
only serve to connect the fights rather than
enhance them.

But the combat at least will give you what
you want.
Especially if what you want is variety.

It&#39;s still unlocking new weapons and fighting
styles right up to the final mission.

Frankly I find that a bit obnoxious, when
the game throws the Mystical Nunchucks at

me when I still haven&#39;t gotten to grips with
the Cerberus Testicle Bolas and the Double
Ended Salad Tongs of Tosh Wahey.

To say nothing of when we switch playable
characters and have to change to a completely

different set of combat controls, which is
like suddenly having to learn to wank with
the other hand.

But I guess you&#39;re supposed to keep practicing,
that&#39;s why it follows the usual DMC tradition

of having about nine million superhard difficulty
settings that just keep unlocking and unlocking

into the stratosphere, and there&#39;s something
very &quot;traditional&quot; about Devil May Cry 5 all
over.

Like it&#39;s more about reestablishing itself
after its time in the Ninja Theory wilderness
than in breaking any interesting new ground.

With the exception of what I hesitate to call
the multiplayer, which just confused the fuck
out of me.

The first I heard about it was after I finished
a chapter and the game went &quot;Would you like
to rate the other player&#39;s performance?&quot;
And I was like, &quot;There was another player?

Fuck, don&#39;t do this to me, DMC, I get quite
enough paranoia from infused gummi bears.&quot;

What it does is, there are several missions
that run parallel to other missions that you

do later as a different character, and in
these cases the game drops in players who

are doing that character&#39;s mission to, I dunno,
lend authenticity.

Harmless enough as gimmicks go, but the problem
was, when other players were in my game, I
don&#39;t think I ever saw the fuckers.

Each character is kept in separated paths
so you can usually only glimpse them through

windows and stuff, and they&#39;d almost always
moved on by the time I got there because I&#39;m

a more methodical player who eats too many
infused gummi bears.

So when they asked me to rate people I just
gave them all a thumbs up whatever.

They could&#39;ve spent the whole mission sitting
in the corner telling all the monsters about

my erectile dysfunction for all I fucking
knew.
But who cares.

I guess Capcom haven&#39;t quite given up on that
dubiously consensual drop-in multiplayer shit

that ran through Resident Evil 6 like skidmarks
on a communal towel, but the actual effect

is so minimal it hardly seems to have been
worth the bother.

Capcom seem to be going through a nostalgia
trip right now and are doing competent enough

work, but while RE2 successfully brought its
subject matter up to date, DMC5 feels more
like going through the old motions.

It delivers if that&#39;s what you&#39;re into, but
be careful, Capcom, you can&#39;t forever smell

your own farts without getting a bit of poo
on your nose.
